definitions.definition: very great; felt or experienced very strongly

examples.text: profound changes in the earth’s climate
My father's death had a profound effect on us all.
The news came as a profound shock.
The report has profound implications for schools.
Her sense of disappointment was profound.
His later articles were a little more profound.
I'm not quite sure what she means by that, but it sounds very profound.

definitions.definition: needing a lot of study or thought

examples.text: profound questions about life and death
She always claimed there was nothing profound about her artwork.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French profund, from Latin profundus ‘deep’, from Latin pro ‘before’ + fundus ‘bottom’. The word was used earliest in the sense ‘showing deep insight’.
